section.name: Assumptions
section.p: This site acts a reference to all project related assumptions. In the upper part of the site you will find valid assumptions, categorised by their domain and scope. In the lower part you will find new, changed or assumptions that are currently under discussion and need approval by the team, or some team members.

For the ease of use, each assumptions has an unique identifier [<identifier>]. This identifier should be short, simple and obvious. Once chosen it shall not be changed, and therefore be stable. If assumptions are refined, or otherwise hierarchically organised an identifier of the form [<parent>:<child>] shall be used.
Discussion of Assumptions takes place at wiki/Assumptions

tr.td: [offline] It is possible to work either online or offline. This implies that two users may work simultaneously on the same document. Hence some form of conflict resolution is needed.
[all_equal] In general, all objects are treated equally; Files, Folders, Notes, etc.
[folder_structure] Folder structure of imported folders is preserved
ease of use, transparency for the user
[project_folder] All shared data lies in one project folder
simplifies implementation, transparency for the user
Feature: [passive_mode] The application can be fully operational even without constant user interaction. That means that the client may passively share data and therefore acts as a dedicated server.
limit the problem of unavailable clients and increase the chance of working with the latest files.
scope of the application, architecture, user interaction

Feature: [soft_lock] Instad of implementing a strict access control systems a soft lock is used. If a user wants to update a file, he/she may be notified that access to the file is somehow restricted. After receiving the notification the user may decide to obey the restriction or not.
no dead- or abandoned locks, no access control required
[push_pull] Concept: Data may either be pushed to, or pulled from a client
[auto_push_pull] The user may indicate whether the application automatically or manually pushes/pulls data. This option may save bandwidth and gives the user more control over the traffic.
save bandwidth, more control over traffic, restrict traffic in insecure environments
[en] The UI and all public documentation are written in english.
[i18n] The application will be prepared for internationalization. UI strings will be handled centrally.
ease of translation, ease of maintenance of the ui
[multi_platform] The application shall run under Windows, Linux and Mac Os X

[single_project] The project is centered around handling one project. An instance of the application will only handle one project and data pertaining to different projects shall be stored in different database files.
simplicity, doing one thing well, clear separation of different projects and simpler data model

[no_chat] It is assumed that project members use a chat client next to the application. We don't want to replace the chat client and don't want to provide chat or group chat functionality. However, leaving a message for other project members (and displaying those) is a use case.
[login] The login is the login to the Interclient Com. It is entered on startup, or can be stored. A person uses only one JID for all of his/her projects.

[supermetadata] Assuming that the [single_project] assumption is accepted (that implies projects are "on their own" and do not know about other projects), a list of subscribed projects will have to be stored at a suitable central location (project installation folder, home directory/"documents and settings" folder,...) and presented to the user before or after login.
need for choosing a project after [single_project]
[notes_with_title_and_text] Notes consist of a title an text. If no title ist set the first line of the text is used instead
that seems quite practical to me... Notes may be displayed only by their title
[remote_personal_metadata] Personal metadata is not stored locally and may be retrieved through the ICC-Service.
No handling of multiple local users.
[no_batch_tagging] It is assumed that the user may only manage tags at one object at a time
simplicity of implementation, although not very user friendly
[single_user] The application supports only one local user per project.
no user switching needed, less security issues
